newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West snowpack way above normal despite rain.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West snowpack way above normal despite rain.

text.p: Despite recent heavy rainstorms in much of the western U.S., snowpack levels remain well above normal, according to official statistics.
"We have had an exceptional year so far, even with the flooding and early snowmelt," said an analyst at the Weather and Climate Center in Portland, Ore.
"We still have a considerable amount of snowpack," he added.

According to the center, a division of the U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service, the water content of snowpack in the Pacific Northwest as of Wednesday ranged from more than 120 percent of average levels at some Oregon sites to above 220 percent at some Idaho sites.
In California, water-equivalent levels stood at between 126 and 232 percent of the average for snowpack on the same day for 1961 through 1990.
A this time a year ago, snowpack levels were much lower, but after cold storms in late January and February snowpack volumes recovered to end at above average levels for the year, the analyst noted.

In 1995, also a year of heavy precipitation on the West Coast, hydropower accounted for almost 65 percent of the electricity used in Washington, Oregon, and California, according to the federal Energy Information Administration.
